name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus, to Clusius, Carolus, 1594-12-30

Diplomatic.text: Carolo Clusio S[alutem] D[icit]. Argumentum te scribendi non habere et tamen scribere, certe amoris est argumentum, mi Clusi. De quo inter nos ambigere qui possumus? Inveteravit iamdiu, et ut annosa arbor quantum vertice ad auras aethereas, tantum radice ad Tartara tendit. Sed mitto blandiri. Germanum nobilem te mystagogo in amicitiae nostrae aedem recepi, et ut tua elogia sunt, non eam maculabit. Valetudinem tibi in hac aetate satis validam esse gaudeo, et diu talem precor; de mea quod quaeris, ambigua est, et ut cum nostro comico, magis varia quam panthera. Tota quidem hac aestate adversa fuit; sperassem meliorem, si Aquis Spadanis uti mihi per terrores vestros licuisset. Videbo quid in proxima erit, si tamen Deus et hanc dabit. Tu, mi Clusi, salve, et hunc ineuntem annum atque alios felix vide. Lovanii, III. Kalend[as] Ianuar[ias] M.D.XCV.

annotations.text: Aquis Spadanis: In 1592 Lipsius had spent a few days in Spa (26 May to 14 June) but he had interrupted his hjourney because of the unremitting rain, cf. ILE V, 92 05 27 DE; 92 06 14 M. In 1593 and 1594 he longed to go, but was very busy with his new works and he also feared that looting soldiers from the Dutch army (terrores vestros) might intervent. Moreover, in the summer of 1594 he had bought a house, which had to be refurbished.

in proxima: In 1595 Lipsius finally returned to Spa from the end of June until 25 July, but soon after his arrival he nearly was caught (and taken hostage) by a group of Dutch cavalrymen. This unfortunate encounter is described at length in a letter to MArtinus ANtonius Delrio, cf. ILE VIII, 95 07 04.
